channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Kerry in Iraq amid Sunni rebel gains
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry arrives in Baghdad as Sunni insurgents expand their control of parts of Iraq.

item.title: High speed rail 'needed in north'
item.description: A new HS3 high-speed rail link connecting Manchester and Leeds could help create a northern "global powerhouse", Chancellor George Osborne says.

item.title: Al-Jazeera trio get seven years jail
item.description: Cairo court sentences three journalists accused of supporting Muslim Brotherhood to seven years in jail

item.title: Mothers have multiple babies removed
item.description: Thousands of mothers over the past seven years have had successive children removed by family courts in England, the BBC learns.

item.title: Tracking all Syria Britons 'impossible'
item.description: Security services will not be able to monitor all of the Britons who return to the country after fighting in Syria, a former MI6 counter-terrorism official says.

item.title: Ghana FA asks for fix claims probe
item.description: The Ghana Football Association calls for police to investigate two men over match-fixing claims made in the Daily Telegraph.

item.title: Asos resumes trading after fire
item.description: Online fashion retailer Asos has started taking orders again after it was forced to suspend trading following a fire at its main warehouse in Barnsley.

item.title: Parties 'using NHS to win votes'
item.description: Nearly three quarters of the public believe the political parties are designing health policy to win votes not to do what is best for the NHS, polling suggests.

item.title: Israeli air strikes target Syria
item.description: Israel says it has carried out air strikes against military targets in Syria, after a teenager was killed by firing from Syria in the occupied Golan Heights.

item.title: S Korean 'killer soldier' captured
item.description: A South Korean soldier who killed five members of his unit is captured after a failed suicide attempt, defence officials say.

item.title: 'Scotland's biggest debate' announced
item.description: BBC Scotland is to host the biggest debate the country has ever seen in the week before the independence referendum.

item.title: Murray ready for Wimbledon defence
item.description: Andy Murray begins the defence of his Wimbledon title with a Centre Court meeting with David Goffin on Monday.

item.title: UK chart to include streaming
item.description: The Official Charts Company announces streaming through services like Spotify, Deezer and Napster will count towards the UK's weekly singles chart from July.

item.title: 'Biggest prize in science' announced
item.description: A British theorist is the first recipient of a new prize for mathematics.

item.title: Redknapp should name names - Gerrard
item.description: Steven Gerrard says Harry Redknapp should "name and embarrass" those players he claims do not want to represent England.

item.title: How Van Gaal got Dutch dazzling again - Seedorf
item.description: Ex-Netherlands international Clarence Seedorf explains the difference new Man Utd boss Louis van Gaal has made to the Dutch at this World Cup.

item.title: World Cup: USA 2-2 Portugal
item.description: Silvestre Varela's injury-time equaliser keeps Portugal in the World Cup as their clash with the USA ends in a draw.

item.title: England inconsistency leaves Test finely balanced - Agnew
item.description: England's shortcomings and a Sri Lanka fightback have set up a wonderful finish to the second Test, says Jonathan Agnew.

item.title: Monday's gossip column
item.description: Barcelona offer £68m for Luis Suarez, Manchester United eye Nigel de Jong, Vela not returning to Arsenal, plus more.

item.title: Iraq, the NHS and Murray and the labradoodle - the papers
item.description: Monday's newspapers look into the future of Iraq and the British Jihadists fighting there, and examine a "£2bn black hole" in the NHS budget.

item.title: VIDEO: Kosovo bridge focus of ethnic violence
item.description: A bridge in the divided town of Mitrovica that has come to symbolise ethnic tensions in north Kosovo has once again been the focus of violence.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Trepidation' ahead of al-Jazeera verdict
item.description: The brother of one of the three al-Jazeera journalists detained in Egypt since December has said he is feeling "trepidation" ahead of a possible verdict in the trial.

item.title: VIDEO: Kara Walker's monumental sugar sculpture
item.description: Most sculptors use stone or sand - but artist Kara Walker has worked with sugar for her monumental exhibition in New York.

item.title: VIDEO: 'People come here to live, not die'
item.description: The BBC's Imogen Foulkes reports on the sport of base jumping and why it is attracting and ever increasing numbers of people who enjoy jumping off mountains with a parachute.

item.title: VIDEO: Trumpington : 'I didn't give a damn'
item.description: Baroness Trumpington spoke to Andrew Marr about her colourful career.

item.title: VIDEO: Huge sinkhole near World Cup stadium
item.description: Houses have been evacuated in a favela near a World Cup stadium in Brazil, after a huge sinkhole opened up.

item.title: VIDEO: LatAm Beats: Panama's Cienfue
item.description: Cienfue is a guitarist and singer from Panama who mixes his country's folk music with popular rhythms and electric guitar, to create a modern amplified sound.

item.title: Honda and Nissan add to airbag recall
item.description: Japanese carmakers Honda and Nissan add 2.8 million vehicles to the recall they issued last year over a defect in passenger airbags.

item.title: VIDEO: Making gelato into big business
item.description: How two friends, an economist and a former wine maker, started a thriving Italian gelato business.

item.title: Labour 'to pause universal credit'
item.description: Labour will "pause" universal credit if it wins the next general election in 2015, shadow work and pensions secretary Rachel Reeves says.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Miliband not celebrity Big Brother'
item.description: Chuka Umunna MP, Shadow Business Secretary told Andrew Marr that the question of Ed Miliband's popularity was 'not celebrity Big Brother'

item.title: 'Sugar tax' call for child obesity
item.description: A campaign group calls on the government to introduce a "sugar tax" to help curb childhood obesity rates in the UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Ebola outbreak is 'out of control'
item.description: The charity Medecins Sans Frontieres has said the Ebola outbreak in west Africa is totally out of control.

item.title: 'Too few pupils' learning languages
item.description: The UK's education system is failing to produce enough people with foreign-language skills to meet a growing need from business, the CBI says.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Bullying has never really stopped'
item.description: Rosie King, 15, describes how her autism has led to her being bullied throughout her years at school and why she and her mother Sharon believe attitudes to disability must change.

item.title: Plan to tackle phone blackspots
item.description: Mobile phone operators could be made to share networks in rural areas where signals are weak, under plans being considered by ministers.

item.title: VIDEO: UK needs better 3G for streaming
item.description: A senior boss at Sony music in Sweden tells Newsbeat streaming will become more popular in the UK with better broadband, 3G and 4G speeds.

item.title: Clue in moon's 'Magic Island' puzzle
item.description: Scientists outline their best explanations for a mysterious feature dubbed the "Magic Island", which has been seen on Saturn's moon Titan.

item.title: VIDEO: Leonardo DiCaprio: eco warrior
item.description: Leonardo DiCaprio pledges to donate seven million dollars for ocean conservation as he addresses a State Department conference on the environment

item.title: Blackadder actress Patsy Byrne dies
item.description: British actress Patsy Byrne, best known for playing Nursie in Blackadder, dies aged 80.

item.title: The man who hoped to die in a railway crash
item.description: Author Jeremy Clay tells the story of the man who rode the railways, hoping to die in a crash.

item.title: Weekendish: Weird contraptions and living goddesses
item.description: Some of the best reads from the BBC News website this week, with your comments.

item.title: Reservoir boy search team finds body
item.description: Divers find a body in a search for a teenager who went missing in an east Lancashire reservoir on Sunday evening.

item.title: 'Mayhem' as balloon lands in street
item.description: A hot-air balloon pilot explains how he "caused mayhem" after he had to land in the middle of a street.

item.title: Two women die after car hits tree
item.description: Two women die and two people are seriously injured after a car struck a tree in Aberdeenshire on Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Glasgow base for chronic pain centre
item.description: A dedicated team offering residential care to people who suffer chronic pain is to be based at the Gartnavel Hospital site in Glasgow.

item.title: Royal couple's visit due to begin
item.description: The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh are due to arrive in Northern Ireland later on Monday for a three-day visit.

item.title: Two are arrested over fatal crash
item.description: Two men are arrested following a crash in west Belfast that killed a 19-year-old man.

item.title: Selling Wales for green investment
item.description: Business people in Wales are joining forces with ministers to try to sell Wales as a great place for green businesses to invest.

item.title: Soaps to screen organ donor adverts
item.description: Viewers of Coronation Street and Pobol y Cwm will be the first to see public information films explaining the change in Wales' organ donor rules next year.

item.title: South Korea 2-4 Algeria
item.description: Algeria move up to second in Fifa World Cup Group H as they overcome South Korea in Porto Alegre.

item.title: Dozens killed in Nigeria attacks
item.description: Dozens of people are killed in a suspected Boko Haram attack on two Nigerian villages near where more than 200 schoolgirls were abducted in April.

item.title: Clashes as Pakistan cleric returns
item.description: Police in Pakistan fire tear gas to disperse hundreds of supporters of prominent anti-government cleric Tahirul Qadri in the capital, Islamabad.

item.title: Egypt set for al-Jazeera verdict
item.description: A Cairo court will issue verdicts on three journalists accused of supporting the Muslim Brotherhood, after a trial condemned by rights groups.

item.title: Clashes at Kosovo blockade bridge
item.description: Demonstrators in Kosovo clash with police over a blockade at a bridge in Mitrovica between the local Albanian and Serb communities.

item.title: Indian 'black money' holders listed
item.description: The Swiss government prepares a list of Indians who have parked un-taxed wealth in Swiss banks and the details are being shared with India, Swiss and Indian officials say.

item.title: Argentina ad rebukes 'vulture funds'
item.description: The Argentine government publishes an advert in US newspapers denouncing the recent US Supreme Court ruling in favour of hedge fund investors holding its defaulted bonds.

item.title: Brazil's Rousseff backed for re-run
item.description: The governing Workers Party in Brazil officially endorses President Dilma Rousseff to run for re-election in October.

item.title: Syria truce over 'desperate' camp
item.description: The Syrian government and rebel groups reportedly agree a truce for Yarmouk refugee camp, where 18,000 are living in desperate conditions.

item.title: US unlocks military aid to Egypt
item.description: The US reveals it has released $575m (£338m) in military aid to Egypt, as Secretary of State Kerry holds talks with the new president in Cairo.

item.title: Canada airlift prisoners recaptured
item.description: Canadian police recapture three prisoners in Montreal who escaped by helicopter from a jail outside Quebec City.

item.title: Woman who invented Kevlar dies
item.description: Stephanie Kwolek, the inventor of Kevlar, the lightweight fibre used in bulletproof vests and body armour, has died at the age of 90.

item.title: Your week in pictures
item.description: Readers' images from the past seven days

item.title: In pictures: Pellet guns maim Kashmir protesters
item.description: The weapons used against Kashmir protestors

item.title: Week in pictures: 14-20 June 2014
item.description: A selection of news photos: 14-20 June 2014

item.title: In pictures: James Lavelle's Meltdown festival
item.description: Music and visual art at London's Southbank

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 June 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 June 2014

item.title: In pictures: Refugee stories
item.description: Photographers talk about their work on World Refugee Day

item.title: In pictures: German caver rescued
item.description: German brought to the surface after a 12-day operation

item.title: Your pictures: Old technology
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of "old technology"

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: A minister claims there is no risk of gas contamination of groundwater by fracking.

item.title: VIDEO: Jihad brothers' 'come home' plea
item.description: The father of two Cardiff brothers who are thought to have travelled to Syria to fight for Islamic extremists says he wants them to come home.

item.title: VIDEO: Tombstone thefts cause for alarm
item.description: The demand for granite and marble in South Africa has seen a big increase in the theft of headstones from cemeteries.

item.title: VIDEO: Tracking all Syria Britons 'impossible'
item.description: The former head of global counter-terrorism at MI6 has warned that the security services will not be able to monitor all of the Britons who return to the country after fighting in Syria.

item.title: VIDEO: Andy Murray: the dog rescuer
item.description: Reigning Wimbledon champion Andy Murray explains how he chased after a dog and returned it to its owner on his way to practice.

item.title: VIDEO: Thousands attend austerity protest
item.description: Campaigners say thousands of people went to an anti-austerity protest in London.

item.title: VIDEO: Thai military stifles dissent
item.description: A month after overthrowing the civilian government in Thailand, the military authorities have moved to stifle all dissent in the country, arresting people for the smallest signs of defiance.

item.title: VIDEO: UK Syria fighters 'long-term threat'
item.description: UK police will have to deal with the threat of British fighters returning from Syria for "many years", a top Scotland Yard officer has told the BBC.

item.title: VIDEO: Pakistan strikes displace 350,000
item.description: Some 350,000 people have left their homes since the launch of a major military offensive in the tribal region of North Waziristan, according to officials.

item.title: The faceless men
item.description: Why did this painting have to be censored?

item.title: In celebration of the 'unknown' Arnold Bennett
item.description: In celebration of the hugely successful Arnold Bennett

item.title: Wimbledon 2014: Li Na courts fans and sponsors
item.description: Chinese megastar Li Na on life as a global tennis brand

item.title: VIDEO: The man behind Wimbledon's grass
item.description: The man behind Wimbledon's grass courts

item.title: VIDEO: Meet God, the Kremlin and Tilda Swinton
item.description: The ingenious world of social media parody

item.title: Who will win the World Cup in 2050?
item.description: Will robots compete with humans?

item.title: How girls can make the best welders
item.description: What it's like to be a female engineering apprentice

item.title: Western Russia aids Ukraine's Cossacks
item.description: What Russians are doing for the separatists in eastern Ukraine

item.title: Australian slang: Your favourite examples
item.description: Your favourite examples of Australian slang

item.title: Pride, pressure, nerves & a runaway dog story
item.description: Pride, pressure, nerves and a runaway dog

item.title: The British are slightly happier than the French
item.description: People in the UK are slightly happier than the French

item.title: The EU's curious choice of president
item.description: Why are EU leaders supporting a man they don't believe in?

item.title: Is Nigeria ready to lead Africa?
item.description: Is Nigeria ready to become the continent's leader?
